description:
After struggling to find some late night eats, a friend and I walked into Blush! We were slightly intimidated by its appearance - it's intimate and extremely classy, so we assumed it would be expensive. Thankfully the prices were pretty reasonable.

Our waiter recommended the bacon & ricotta ravioli ($16). It came out steaming hot with some crispy bread on the side. While I didn't have taste buds after my meal, it was creamy and delicious. It was pretty rich but I still wanted more! While a little pricy, I had no regrets (even though my lactose intolerance was acting up...).

The only disappointing aspect was that our waiter wasn't the friendliest. After reading some of the other reviews about how staff wasn't friendly however, I don't take it personal. I personally think it enhances your dining experience when you feel welcomed. However, although somewhat preoccupied, our waiter was quick to take our order and fulfill any requests we have.

For a classy dining experience before your night out partying it up with amazing people in Castro, check out Blush!
author: Abby C.

description:
One of my favorite wine bars in the Bay Area--I love that the house wines are all European and that there are organic and biodynamic options too :).

DRINKS: what a fantastically curated menu! I've never had a wine here I didn't like, and they have many of my favorites (no claim to being a oeno/expert here) including a House Montepulciano, Sancèrre, and some lovely darker red blends (my favorite!). 

Happy hour (until 6pm) is choose your own adventure at 30% off all wines. 

FOOD: There are cheese plates and other smaller bites that looked appetizing! Hope to try sometime soon :). 

SERVICE: so friendly! Never felt rushed (I do in most wine bars) and appreciated our server's high indecision tolerance. Everyone working there was open and ready to help--easy to flag someone down for whatever reason (more drinks, question about the wine list, bathroom low on toilet paper). 

AMBIANCE: perfect for a first or hundredth date or catch-up. There's a good mix of counter, table, bar, and couch seating--something for everyone (well, comfortably groups up to 10)! The lighting is charmingly dim without the hazards of darkness (looking at you, Local Edition). It's cozy, but doesn't feel small given the high ceilings and many nooks settle in. Overall, a welcome oasis amid all the fun craziness that is the Castro at night :).
author: Helen W.

description:
Quaint little bar in Castro street 
I loved their ambience.
Very classy and quiet.

I went with my friends and had an awesome time chatting and drinking in here.
author: Vani J.

description: Lovely casual atmosphere with great selection of wines and small plates. Live music and art on the wall make it a delightful destination.
author: Nils H.

description: This place is awesome one of the best Classy casual places to take a date or to have a business meeting there are no TVs in here which I like and the wine selection as I was getting rotated it's a must go to visit in San Francisco
author: Casey V.

description: This is a place I go to a lot even though it's not my favorite wine. The vibe is chill, it's next to lots of other spots I like, and the happy hour drink deal is good... But I've also had a number of wines by the glass here that I don't adore here. Some are quite sweet? Others quite plastic? Hard to pin... But there are some interesting things like a pink pinot gris and a sparkling  red that are fun to try even if they aren't my fave. The staff are honest as you find your way through the wine list and can help you avoid things you wouldn't like. The tapenade and bruschetta and edamame hummus are all good but overpriced for the portions. Love the ambiance-- could hang here for hours.
author: Anastasia Z.

description: If you need a glass of wine, stop by. If you like good wine go the Molly Stones and buy a $25 of red and drink it at home.
author: Lee H.

description: One of the best wine bars I've ever been to... Elliot is the best bartender ever. Cheese board was great, wine recs were amazing. If you want to have a good time, join the Blush family.
author: Ashley G.

description:
Cute little wine bar in the heart of the Castro. We dropped by for pre-theater drinks, and managed to score two stools before the place got completely swamped.

THE OVERVIEW.
+ Daily happy hours, which is nice, although it still feels expensive
- Very limited parking out front
- Noise level can get quite high, and you end up having to compete with other parties around you to see who can yell and laugh the loudest
- The food is over-priced, for the portion sizes

Not my cup of tea (or wine, for that matter), but gets the job done.
author: Claire S.

description:
Wine was too good.they had of variety of wine .my husband's beer. came in a decorative flask
 Ambience of this bar was also good. Planing to come here again with friends.
author: Prerna M.

description:
Twas the afternoon of Cinco de Mayo. I rode the Rainbow-lit-escalator up from the muni station into the vivacious heart of Castro. Thirsty, I sauntered over to Blush! An adorable sign boasted a seven-day-a-week happy hour. Thirsty, I ordered a glass of prosecco from the charming bartender. I proceeded to people watch the hustle and bustle of Castro street while sipping my effervescence.

Later, my companion arrived and we moved to a scarlet, velvet couch in the back. I sipped a glass of dry, Jacquère. The bartender was kind enough to pour me a taste before I committed to a generous glass. We sat, chatted and took in the wonderful neighborhood of a wine bar. Although, It appeared the majority of customers were regulars, I felt quite welcome. I would definitely return to try more of the unique offerings in such a quaint establishment.

Funny Note: 
A customer asked if one of the bartenders was celebrating Cinco de Mayo. The server embraced the other server and cried, "We are French! We do not celebrate Cinco de Mayo! We lost!"
author: Backwordbender F.

description:
I've been here twice now and really like the quiet and chill ambiance of the wine bar. It's conveniently located right across the street from the Castro Theater, if you and your friends just finished watching a show and want to grab a drink or two before heading home. 

Both times I've been, there were 5-6 of us and it was never too crowded that we couldn't find seats immediately, which is impressive given its prime location in the Castro. We came around 10 pm on a Friday and Saturday night, respectively, so I was surprised we could find seating so easily.The set up is varied with some larger communal tables, some cozy looking couches, and some private tables that are perfect for a group of 5-6 people.

I've never had the food here, but I've consistently gotten their sangria ($8 a glass) which is delicious if you like sweeter drinks like me. Note that it's probably one of the sweetest sangrias I've ever had, so if sweet drinks aren't your thing, stay far away from the sangria here and try one of their many wines instead.

Parking here is all along the street. The last time I came my friend drove and it was shocking to me how we were able to find an open spot right in front of Blush. So it is possible but I would recommend ubering or lyfting instead to be safe, especially on a busy Friday/Saturday night.
author: Dianna H.

description:
I don't have one positive thing to say about this place. If I listed everything I hated I would waste more time then this awful spot is worth.  The staff were rude and kept vanishing (it wasn't even busy) so you have to stand around at the bar and wait forever to order a drink. They also rang me up wrong twice and didn't give me the happy hour price, but I was so done with the spot I just overpaid so I could GTFO.

I would spend your time and money elsewhere and at places that are more representative of the awesome welcoming spirit this city is about.
author: Mel M.

description: Elliot is my favorite! Went here for a girls night out on Saturday night and had so much fun! Delicious wine, people, and yummy cheese platter. I always love coming here!
author: R I.

description:
I have been here four different times and I can't quite figure out what's up with the bartenders.  Are they too pretty to make drinks? Do they not like women?  Are they hungover from the night before?  This is a 4 star wine bar with 2 star service, so what to do?  I keep coming back but have started sending friends up to the bar to order, they get the same response or lack thereof, so... Just be forewarned and maybe you'll get the guys on a good night, or just be patient, they'll eventually get around to waiting on you.
Things I like:
* interesting wine and priced fairly for SF (read expensive)
* great location
* rustic hip interior
* good food
author: Virginia T.

description: Great atmosphere, wine and nibbles...however the service is less than adequate.  The dude-bros behind the bar appear more entertained with one another than being attentive to their patrons.  Once you get their attention, again it becomes lack luster.  We ordered a bottle, he opened it and walked away.  Didn't even bother to pour the glasses.  I want the place to succeed, and clearly it will as the tech kids that stop in have no idea what service looks like.  Dudes, show some service and appreciation for your clients...it's not that tough!
author: Randy M.

description: This is a great wine bar if you are in the area. Great selection of wines and the food is great as well. Price is reasonable! Great find in the Bay Area!
author: Andrea P.

description:
I took my best friend here after a tan we got at Tan Bella , we wanted to some girl time to chat and sip some wine/champagne w| little snacks. 
my best friend had never been in the Castro - me , i have had MANY fun full nights there. Lol.! Although i am not 21 anymore, this Friday night required more wine than those awesomely dangerous 2-4-1's deals.. LOL!
So we went in since it was close, and we had such a relaxing time. Service was good.! We got our menu's and then our order taken in less than 10 minutes. Everything came out pretty quick too.! They had a good selection of wines and champagnes, and every better selection of snacks to compliment the wines.. 
It took awhile to get our check but then again we didn't ask for it.. Lol! (we were caught up in our conversation) I can say it is pricey - we got three plates and 2 glasses each and it was 100$ even, which i guess isn't HORRIBLE but i mean i guess what wine bar isn't Lol.! However, i would defiantly be going back ;)
author: Silvia R.

description:
This is a generous 3 stars; I should have given 2-2.5

Wanted to love this place, unfortunately did not. Service was okay, and the food wasn't bad, but the portion we got for the cheese platter was pathetic. $18 for three tiny pieces of cheese and a handful of crackers and airy bread... Eighteen whole dollars. Two of the three cheeses were tasty and the bread was warm, but that should have been a $10-12 plate, max.

Also, the layout and seating arrangements were a bit awkward. I really, really wanted to like Blush! Bummer.
author: Nic Z.

description: I met a friend here the other night - checking out a new (for us) wine bar. Had glass of rose and shared the pruschito/goat cheese sandwich which comes with a side salad. Wine was nice and food tasted ok for what you would expect in a wine bar. Service was actually attentive. But during the night I got sick - checked in with my friend and the same had happened to her. Not sure if it was the lettuce or pruschito or maybe the cheese. But nevertheless will.not.return.
author: Robin P.

description: Ironically this wine bar has the best Belgian beer in the Castro. They also have great snack plates to nibble on as you sip and chat. It's a great date place; lively yet quieter than the surrounding bars. The staff are also friendly. A nice classy alternative to the frankly dumpy bars nearby full of cranky drunks trolling Scruff.
author: Steven G.

description:
When I was young, I wanted to be a writer, a poet, a lounge singer and a journalist. I had wanted to sing at a place like this, dark and trendy, good wine but not too crowded so that you can still hear your companion at a respectful distance.  It also possible to take small breaks and mingle around the tables scattered around this bar, without bumping into sweaty people. I did not think a French wine bar existed in many places in this part of the town. In part, I was never looking for such things. If I wanted a French bar, I would have gone to one at my home in France but that's too far, too ambitious and unnecessary when a good one is just across the street from the Castro theatre.

I arrived last week after a long day at work, honestly thought I was late but I was the first to arrive. Promptly ordered a glass of bubbly Rose and grabbed a table because my girlfriend often arrives with her entourage and that evening it was no exception. Soon six of them arrived, separately and then some together, they complimented my seating arrangement. We all set at a communal table, pleasantries exchanged. Noted two new people from Brooklyn, musicians, who I had not met before, one friend I already knew, some musician who lives in Cole Valley, a Bavarian girl I've known through a gallery outing and then my girlfriend who was an ageless lady who used to belly dancing naked in the early years of Blackrock city, now a perennial fixture among the musicians and artist in town. She literately knows everyone and is friends with everyone in town. So you get the gist. This bar attracts artist types who came in that evening to watch a band. It's a good place for likeminded people to gather, to have a good meal and then listen to some tunes. 

I ordered appetizers for the table. Ever feel that you are the lucky one who did well for yourself and you should be more generous among your artist friends? Well, I do. I always feel too sheltered and too lack of artistry. The only thing I'm good at is to eat food. So I ordered two things and they arrived shortly. They edamame spread was quite clever. I liked it a lot. The musicians playing that evening were quite good. French gypsy music was quite suitable for this bar. 

It's low key. Meaning, you don't have to scream and yell to talk and to be heard. The ambience is chill. And the food is good. The wine selection is robust. Stick with French, but of course.

Will likely bring other friends of mine over here for meal and music.
author: Victoria E.

description: Love this place. You can't go wrong with their Happy Hour 30% off all bottles of wine. Our server Gabriel is the best in the City. He always makes us fell welcomed. Do yourself a favor and check Blush out soon.
author: Teresa M.

description: Gorgeous spot for a glass of wine. Extremely friendly staff and extensive selection of wine.
author: Steven W.

description: The bartenders are really welcoming and great, they have a very good curated wine selection and some tasty French Food.
author: Val V.

description:
Blush is an excellent, calming place to decompress with friends after work. 

Their wine selection is very good, their food is different and yet appropriate for the French bistro feel, and the atmosphere is conducive to gentle conversations and sedate people watching.

I am a red wino, so a bottle of tempranillo with a cheese plate is a nifty set up to catch up with friends. There are corners, chairs, tables, and nooks that let you find a place for conversation. 

Okay, sometimes at Friday happy hours the noise level is frenetic, but deciding to go there on a Wednesday instead of a Friday solves that problem!

Vincent and his staff are low-key and friendly, and they know their wines without being snobby.

It's one of my go-to places when my non-wino friends are not going out. And, their 30% off happy hour wine prices are appreciated.

[The music noise I wrote about in the earlier review has disappeared, btw.]
author: Galen W.

description:
Wow, cannot say enough about this place. 

Service was phenomenal, we had two French bartenders that gave out free drinks if you made the cork in their bucket. What started as a quick stop turned into a night of great wine and a decent beer selection to top it off. 

Ambience is great, it's a little bit of an older crowd but can't critique that. I just can't get over the outstanding bartenders; they seemed to really care that their customers were enjoying their drinks and the bar itself. 

The wine was not too expensive, overall a blast. Must stop in Castro for a more laid back night.
author: Sam R.

description:
Rose and Creamy Buratta make my week. They have really yummy snacks and the bartenders are welcoming. For the solo sipper you can rest assured you'll feel comfortable going here. They also have fun themed activities different nights of the week, including having your fortune told. I'm a cheese person so I could most likely eat here for the rest of my life and be perfectly happy 
 Can you say Yum?
author: Heather J.

description: Love Blush!  Really cool vibe and good happy hour prices.  The wine and beer menu is on point and the location is convenient.  My go to place to meet friends for drinks!
author: Lynda M.

description: I'm always down for a glass of wine or even a bottle, especially at half off during happy hour at Blush!  With so many enticing happy hour spots in the Castro, I opted to go to Blush with two friends.  Blush has a decent amount of seating at the bar and table-wise.  We found ourselves at the bar on a Wednesday afternoon.  Friend ordered a bottle of Omen (50% off $52) for three of us to share along with a cheese plate ($18).  The cheese selection included 3 French cheeses with the usual hard, soft and goaty, accompanied by crackers and warm bread.  Good wine bar, but nothing really stood out about the place.  The service was a bit lackluster as well.  Happy hour prices very appealing though!  Might come back if I were in the neighborhood, but would opt to check out another wine bar first.
author: Liv A.

description: The bartender Christopher was MIA, talking to 2 girls for like 2 hours without paying attention to anyone else. Very rude and unprofessional attitude. This place seem nice from outside, but the staff is careless and inattentive to certain customers.
author: Nick G.

description:
This place is really lovely and intimate. If you want to take someone on a date who loves wine, come here.

Wines run around $9-12/glass from my memory with bottles available as well. If you're not into wine they had $6 sangria when I came and a few beers on tap.

Longish bar area, a fair amount of tables, one community table, and a couch area near the front.

If you're feeling a classy night out as a person who can adult with some wine on your mind, Blush awaits you dear!
author: Connie H.

description:
I came here after work for a happy hour and enjoyed the low key vibe and decor. We got here around 4:45 and it wasn't too busy, which was nice. 

We had appetizers that were pretty enjoyable. We had the burrata with honey and sea salt, Croque Monesieur (really good), and it was an unexpected treat to have escargot!
author: Kelly F.

description:
Awesome wine bar with great nibbles. I had a delicious Sancerre my husband a Pinot Gris. We had an appetizer of smoked trout crostini, very good.
Friendly staff with a nice atmosphere.
author: Monica D.

description:
12/03/2017 - Walked in and was completely ignored by the two employees behind the bar. The actual wine may have been delicious, but I never got the chance to try any. Also, I'm not a big fan of people drinking on the job...but maybe that's just how they roll here. 

Went 1 block down to another establishment, and was immediately greeted with a warm welcome, great service, and wine.
author: Jeff W.

description: Came in on a recommendation.  Very disappointing.  Was told they were closed although door was open and the bartender just served a table.  Both Yelp and the times posted on door indicated they are open. I have been to several wine bars across the city and I was unimpressed with the customer service.  No thanks.
author: Laura F.

description:
Christopher was fantastic, and his wine recommendation was wonderful with the crab and avocado bruschetta. He even plugged my phone in to charge so I wouldn't be struck traveling back to Emeryville on my own late at night with no phone. 

Unfortunately, I initially chose Blush because I saw escargot on their menu online and was excited to have that for my late dinner after a long day of exploring the city. Sadly, they had just 86'd escargot from the menu, hence the bruschetta. It was delicious, though, and the charcuterie board the other gentleman at the bar enjoyed also looked delicious. 

I do hope to come back when I eventually bring my wife to explore the city by the bay, but we'll be hitting before 6pm, when the wines are half price for happy hour.
author: da j.

description:
Reason for loosing a star: This is not the fault of the actual place but the hours on yelp for the weekends are not correct. This caused my friends and I to explore around Castro for 45 mins before it opened, granted the street has many places to wonder in and explore so it wasn't too bad. I only noticed the late opening (10 mins, so really not that big of a deal) because we were literally standing outside. Also they were not completely ready at the time the store said they would be, in terms of kitchen staff and decor. 

Came here one weekend with my two high school friends to chat, drink, and eat. We walked in right when they opened the doors and clearly they were not 100% ready. The kitchen staff does not come in for another 30-45 mins after the opening so any food orders just took a little longer. The candle light decorations had yet to be lit and placed around the room either so it was a rather dark and uninviting environment. Once properly set up though, the place was rather charming with selves of wines, coaches, more private tables, and a bar. 

We also weren't aware but we came in during happy hour (daily 4-6pm) and all wines were 50%, yay! I am not a professional wine taster so sadly you cannot fully trust my taste on the "good stuff" but I can say there was a good selection of options. We ordered a bottle of Moscato for $18 after the 50% off (that screams girl-drinkers, I know! Partially ashamed, partially not.) and a large assorted board ($38). The board though! It really went well with a glasses of wine and I fell in love with the olive tasting spread, yum!

The service was super friendly with the two interactions we had. Once when the kitchen staff apologized for the wait with the food they brought out and the second time when were were brought out our wine and asked if we wanted the option of chilling the remaining amount in the bottle, considerate. Overall, I think they were busy opening and could tell we wanted to chat and catch up, so they left us relatively alone which was fine for me. 

End note: I would love to come here during happy hour again but I would double check the times they are actually open and maybe wonder in 20 mins after they open.
author: Maybo H.

description: I love this place every time I go hear the staff is   On point the food is so good the wine is great I like to go here on dates but it's also fun to take a family member for a nice glass of wine and a few bites of cheese
author: amanda l.

description: There are very few times in life when wine taste as good as this the atmosphere the ambience to service the food everything was absolutely amazing this is a go to spot if you're ever in San Francisco California
author: Casey M.

description: I love this place every time I go here the atmosphere is absolutely phenomenal the service is great it's a great place for a first date or casual drink with a friend
author: Tarif W.

description: Good luck ever being waited on if you're not a local! Drinks and food are good if you can get waited on! Go elsewhere! Not that special
author: Harry P.

description:
Love it here!  Christopher is an amazing bartender.  He knows his wine and isn't afraid to give his phone number out.  Wait.  I mean...

Seriously, he lived in Italy, studied sculpture, and isn't afraid to give his honest opinions of the wine - which coincide with reality vs. being pretentiously vague and verbose.  And he's really interested in you _liking_ what you order, too, helping you find what appeals vs. just getting drunk.

Got the cheese plate that included a triple cream that was amazingly light and creamy, like butter, but better.  But the cheese selection seems to change daily.  I'd trust it.
author: Sondra H.

description:
I want to love this place. I really do. It's the only wine bar in my neighborhood (the Castro), it's pretty cute inside and the staff is friendly enough, and because of all that they do a consistently good business. But there is one major drawback: MEDIOCRE WINE. 

Honestly, I wonder why I keep going back despite the convenience, because every time I try a different glass and hope I will finally find that one exceptional wine, I am disappointed. Every time! In all the years they've been there I'm not sure they've changed the wine menu much but I guess it works for most people because business does not suffer. To me, however, their $12-14 glasses taste like the $12-14 bottles I get at the corner store. I have no problem paying that price for a glass of wine, I just want it to rock my world a little bit.

Two positive things to note. They have an amazing happy hour special... 1/2 off all glasses and bottles, which is honestly the only time I go anymore because that's the only time their mediocre wine selection has a justifiable and appropriate price. Secondly, the food menu, while a bit on the plain side at least as far as the cheese and charcuterie platters go) has always been consistently tasty. (Probably because it's helping the mediocre wine go down better.)

Overall, this place has the potential to be *outstanding* but kinda falls flat. But it's conveniently located and a nice place to hang out, so as long as your taste expectations are on the lower side, it'll be fine.
author: Bella B.

description:
What a fun find.  This place offers happy hour specials every day for 1/2 off glasses of wine ($5-6 for a generous pour of wine, me-thinks "yes!").  We haven't tried any of their food, but will be trying their charcuterie or cheese plate at some point.  The couple next to us ordered the cheese plate, which looked delicious and offered a generous portion of cheese/bread/spreads (not the typical miniscule portion of cheese I've come to expect when ordering one out at most wine bars in the city).

Will definitely be back.
author: Rachael S.

description:
I think it's saying something that I spent the entire day in Napa before coming to this wine bar, and I'm still sitting down to write this place a 4-star review. (Yes, I drank a lot of wine that day...) This is a really great place for a classy but simple get-together with a few friends. The atmosphere is casual but classy, not too loud or crowded while maintaining an energetic vibe. They're open late and have a decent amount of seating, which means you can sit with a friend and chat comfortably into the night over a few glasses of wine.

Of course, we should talk about the wine: Most importantly, this place has a huge selection of wines! They have wine of all kinds from all over the world, and many wines aren't even on the menu, so ask the staff if you're looking for something in particular. For someone like me, who admittedly doesn't know much about the wine, the staff is really helpful. All you need to do is describe the type of taste you're looking for and they'll make sure you're satisfied. They even let you taste a particular wine first before you get a full glass. The wine selection is mostly reasonably priced at ~$10-12 a glass, so you can feel fancy without paying too much for it.

Important note: I didn't try the food, but I'd like to! I'll be back the next time I'm looking for a place to spend a quiet night out with a few friends.
author: Brittany C.

description:
A nice and chill wine bar with really nice bartenders. I made a comment about Barbera (they're popping up on menus now and that makes me really happy) and the bartender gave me a taste of another bottle that he had sitting there. 

It's a great place to come, chill, have a glass of wine and good conversation with a friend before or after dinner.
author: Mariko F.

description:
I watched the Americano social club at Fillmore Jazz Festival and have been meaning to go see them at Blush on Thursdays and I finally got a chance to do that. 

The bar was packed, but there was still enough space to stand, enjoy some music and grab a wine.

They have a big wine menu. Slightly on the pricey side. I had a glass of Riesling for $11. But worth it for the music !
author: Priyanka P.

description: Worst service ever. Took a while to even be seated upon arrival. After seated, waiter ignored us for about 20 minutes (in a small and uncrowded room.) We didn't even get a drink order in. Making eye contact amidst his chatter with customers failed so I finally stood up to the bar to ask to order. Finally got the food. Escargot tasted very foul. Escargot shouldn't taste like urine, people. Too busy to ask if anything tasted well or for a refill. No conversation or manners as they were much too curt with us. Struggle just to get the check. I'm a queer woman but felt like being the only 'hetero' couple there screwed us over. He was very friendly and kind to the other patrons which were all male and very classically homosexual men. We were both very quiet and polite for the entirety. Bummer - Won't be back.
author: Nicole S.

description: Yesterday was my first time at Blush! and I had the most fabulous experience with the best waitress ever, Kianna! The drinks are delicious, the service is great, and the vibes are awesome!
author: Jasreen K.

description:
We've been going to Blush for years and haven't any issues until now. Sure there's good ravioli, variety of wines and somewhat uncomfortable chairs; service can be slow and the ambiance ranges from nice couch, bar to picnic table. Ours was an issue of service and accommodation. My partner has a painful back condition that really is helped if he puts his feet up on another chair, which he's done pretty much every time we've gone. We're not talking reclining with feet up on a table but just propped up onto another chair so as to relieve the pressure coming up the legs from the concrete floors to his back. It's certainly not a sign of disrespect. 

Every time we've been there nad he's done there was never a reaction, no comments, nothing even if they're busy. They've had a good track record of accommodation too. We bring our big serivce dog there regularly and never even had an eyelash batted at us. 

But for some reason tonight (which wasn't busy) the staff was having none of the foot-raising. And instead of asking why his feet were up or asking him to put them down the rather animated (and jerky) security/staff skipped right ahead to kicking us out after curtly announcing that, "you need to leave right now." And that was the end of our night. All in all the episode was more shocking to us more than anything else. It seems as if staff needs to get a refresher on customer service and empathy.
author: Kevin H.

description: Don't just come in for the wine...the food and Belgium beer selection is worth it. Burrata with walnuts/honey and the wild mushrooms ravioli...so creamy good!  Busy happy hour so calling for attention was not unexpected especially with a full bar.
author: Debbie T.

description: Fun ambiance with an excellent wine list complemented by delicious food offerings. The bartenders are always friendly and accommodating with a good knowledge of their wine list. Excellent space for the solo taster or groups of friends. The decor is augmented by the display of talented local artists.I am definitely a repeat patron.
author: Scott V.

description:
I came here once for Happy Hour with a friend. No wait I missed it by 10 minutes... boo. Their Monday HH special is awesome, though. 50% off all glasses of wines! I'm going back just for that. Actually I would generally visit Blush for a glass of wine and maybe a charcuterie platter. The more substantial food menu has never appealed to me during all the times I've walked by, but I will probably give it a try sooner or later.

The Burrata ($10) is quite excellent, and I would recommend it. The bartenders are chill, and the service is nothing special. This wine bar really is about you and your friends. Come here, drink wine, and have a good time!
author: Stefanie C.

description: Don't bother! Bartenders have no concept of customer service , are inept and so slow. Many other places to spend your money. What a waste of time.
author: Barry E.

description: Horrible experience. Went in on a Sunday afternoon for a casual glass of wine and cheese board and was surprised at the extremely poor service here at Blush. Went up to the bar to order and was ignored for a good 10 minutes. They served the bigger party before giving me any attention, then started to pour their glasses before even asking what I'd like to order. Just said "hold on" in a very rude tone without any eye contact. Then once the bar tender was done servicing the bigger party he decided to close out two different parties before even giving me a moment of his time. I then gave up and went to my Wife & told her I was ready to go... I did not want to give this place anymore of my time. She decided to give it a try and she got the same rude attitude, was tossed the "correct" menu and ignored once more. Love the Jackie Kennedy decor, love the concept, but the bartender they got back there is rude AF. He makes you want to take your money elsewhere...and so we did. Choose another cute wine bar stop before settling here- you'll be glad you did.
author: Suzanne S.

description: What a wonderful wine bar! Very friendly and knowledgeable bartenders that make great wine recommendations. Intimate and classy ambience. Great for a date or to catch up with a friend. Good food (I had the escargot) and great wines! They even have fun events throughout the week. I'll be coming back for Dirty Bingo on Monday nights!
author: Jaching H.

description:
Had the procuitto sandwich and a beer.
The Sandwich was ok, the beer was good, and the bartender was friendly and accommodating.
author: Chelsea D.

description: Ok wines but WORST service in the city!! After 10 minutes at the bar, patiently waiting, the server walking by us multiple times and doing everything possible not to acknowledge us or make eye contact, we were finally asked what we wanted. There was no sense of urgency, concern or care whether we stayed or left. Frankly, the two people working at the very empty bar were less than willing to help anyone and made it apparent that neither wanted to be there... There are much better places in the city you can invest your time and money in.
author: Meli L.

description: I'm having their Kalamata Tapenade as well as their Edamame Hummus.  The place is totally packed!  :-)
author: Victor J.

description: Nice bar with a happy hour wine special. We got a few glasses of their wine and got a Charcuterie board which were all good.
author: Patrick W.

description: Nice change of pace in the Castro.  Great in the late afternoon before it gets too crowded.  Friendly bartenders.  Fast service (when not crowded).  Tasty food from a small but well thought-out menu.  Good wine selection at reasonable prices (inflated but no worse than usual). Soft, interesting music.  Dark and comfortable (except for the bright glare from the front window until it gets dark out).  Much nicer than your typical Castro fare. A comfortable place to relax and unwind.
author: R L.

description:
Sweet-Baby-Jeezus. Could the staff have been any more disinterested in our presence? Seriously, I felt like an impediment to their wellbeing. It also interrupted their beer drinking. Mind you, I enjoy a good beer drinking server like the next person - as long as they take care of business.

The wine list is seriously limited and the food outrageously overpriced. Thank gawd for the latter, the lighting is so fucking dim you can hardly see what the hell is being served.

Save your money and good vibe and take it somewhere else - anywhere else.
author: Daniel L.

description:
Came here a few times with some friends. 4-6pm happy hour on Monday through Friday which is amazing! Half off of glass of wines. The white wines are so delicious. 

We ordered the Burrata together once and it was delicious. I do love a good burrata. It's a cheese that I've really fallen in love with. Anyways, this one was delicious as always. 

Protip: Go for happy hour!
author: Nina Y.

description: I always have a great experience at Blush. Vincent, Elliott, Gabe, Christopher (sorry if I am forgetting someone else) are very friendly and attentive. Food is great, and the live entertainment is wonderful. I'm glad this place is in my neighborhood.
author: Nelson G.

description: Cute wine bar in the Castro. The cheese plate was good, wasn't really a fan of the sandwich I had though. It was the ricotta one. It's a cute spot when you wanna get together with a friend for some wine outside of your house.
author: Nawal W.

description:
Great wine, lovely atmosphere, excellent service.  This is a great place to take someone right before dinner for a glass/bottle of wine.  I say this because that's exactly what we did - came here for a bottle of central coast CA Pinot before going out for sushi.

Oh, and let's discuss the insanely hot tattooed, muscle-bear bartender.  OMFG.  Yes.  Yes.  And, double-yes.
author: Michael D.

description:
A little dark and dingy and who knows what happened on that old velvet couch but we'll lounge there anyways, yeah, that's part of our Sunday afternoon adventure.

Came here with my sweetie and 2 friends post Beach Blanket Babylon and the place was pretty empty at 4pm on a Sunday.  The service was friendly and our waitress even offered us a tasting of the wines as we were indecisive.  Their chardonnay and pinots were both excellent but the cheese plate at $16 was just some measly pieces of toast and 4 pieces of cheese.  No dried fruit?  Wines weren't too expensive but not cheap either.  Wine bars to me are suppose to be intimate, romantic, cozy.  This place is none of the above.  The ambiance makes me feel like I'm hanging out at some unclean high school friend's basement.

Not too bad of a hangout spot but definitely not a place for romance or dressing up.  Throw on your dingy 3 day old jeans and converse and you'll blend right in.
author: Yue L.

description: Omg worst experience ever... I love this place but last night I felt so so rushed and our server was not so nice... I miss the other guy with tattoos.. but sadly and disappointed with service last night
author: daezi s.

description:
My friends and I decided to come here yesterday and skip the crazy cheap happy hours around to enjoy some wine instead. The place is really chill. There was only one server so it took some time, but she was pretty good at checking up on us and updating us to let us know our food was coming.

We all got a glass of wine and ordered a mixed platter which came with toasted sourdough bread, 2 cheeses, prosciutto and salami with whole grain mustard. I really liked the everything on the plate. I didn't care much for the prosciutto here but the Brie was really soft and creamy! 

Overall, decent service. The food was good and the wine was good, minus the sangria that I tried a sip of and didn't like. Other than that, I'd come back.
author: Vi L.

description: I really liked this place.  It's very cute and there is a nice wine selection.  I can't rate the food because I just came in for happy hour but the sangria was pretty good and they have happy hour on Sunday which you rarely see in SF.   I definitely will be coming back. The only thing it's missing is outdoor seating.
author: Diana D.

description:
Sometimes, you go to a wine bar and have a nice glass of wine with a friend.

Sometimes, you go to a wine bar, pay $13 for a mediocre red, and realize halfway through that you'd be happier with a $2 PBR. Sophistication stings.

And sometimes, you go to a wine bar and meet Christopher. You talk about what two 45-year-olds on a Tinder date looks like. You talk about artisanal Christmas tree farms in Vermont. You get another pour even though they're closed. You talk about whether trust fund babies' burden falls on them or their friends. You drink a non-Chimay Belgian out of a Chimay glass because you embrace blasphemy. You talk about the merits of tattooing a Twitter bird on your back.

Yes, sometimes you go to a wine bar and remember that what you're drinking doesn't really matter. In isolation, $13 glasses of wine are almost never worth it. But combine great company with a great bartender, and you've got yourself a deal.

Thanks, Christopher! Save the first tree for us.
author: Peter S.

description:
Kristin is the bomb diggity. She not only hooked us up with bottomless mimosas and food, but took an Ellen style flawless selfie. 

We went in for a birthday and the mimosas were strong, food was good, and the music was perfect. This place is never too crowded for brunch and is an awesome addition to the Castro. Saturday morning turn up!!
author: Symone M.

description:
Love this joint! We came on a Thursday night after having dinner at Catch and the featured act for the evening was gypsy jazz.  I can't recall having heard gypsy jazz before so I was intrigued.  Turns out the band was good.  They played some lively show tunes and a number of popular tunes that are well familiar to anyone with some semblance of popular American culture.  
We wanted a relaxing evening with good wine and good live music.  Well, this place more than delivered.
author: Michael L.

description:
I know, I know, it's the city. I get it, the buildings are old. Of course they don't have good air conditioning (or any). But it still killed me that on the hottest day of the summer, I popped in here to meet a friend and it was about 90F inside. That's SO not a relaxing place to have a glass of wine. It's just not.

Three stars because it's cute, well-located, and has a nice wine selection... but... oy the lack of circulation on a hot day.
author: Sean B.

description:
The big white muscly bartender was a bully.  He seemed miffed about something, and wouldn't get our check or refill our wine glasses, after some polite and friendly prompting.

There were only 4 of us at the bar.

We're usually easy customers.  It would be nice, if they could hire someone else.
author: Christopher N.

description: Great Ambiance, solid wine list and great service....I can't say enough good things about this wine bar..We stopped here to kill a few hours before heading to SFO for our flight..We ended up buying a bottle or so and the bartender was gracious enough to comp two of our glasses of wine. The ambiance is great to just sit in, have conversation in and relax. I will definitely be back next time I am in the Castro.
author: Shawn M.

description: Love this little wine bar!  Have been here several times, last night it was for dinner before the Moth Grand Slam at the Castro Theater.  Wonderful list of wines which you can enjoy at the bar, or at one of the tables, small and large.  Last night we had the Cheese Board - yummy and served with plenty of bread, crackers, and fruit - usually a problem that leaves you awkwardly eating cheese remains with your fingers, the Arugula Salad -- really fresh and tasty, and the B.L.A.T. Sandwich -- bacon deliciousness.  The service was super friendly, too.  We had to head out before the live music started:  tough choice - good jazz or storytellers across the street?  But we'll be back -- and that's a guarantee!
author: Lisa W.

description: This is cutest place I have every been too. I wish we had places like this in SoCal! The bartender was so nice and gave me and my friends an amazing experience. The food is so tasty for bar food too. We all gathered by the open bar by the street view window and enjoyed the characters of the castro!
author: Cecily B.

description: This place is a great place! They have a wide selection of wines for any kind of wine fan. I had the fortunate timing of coming in when Andrea is working. She couldn't have made me more comfortable while I was there. We talked a great deal and her knowledge and costumer service ability are 5 stars without hesitation. When you walk in it's as if your transported to a friends house for a glass of wine. Easy decor, comfortable couches, and fantastic staff. This is a must for anyone wanting to relax and have a great glass of wine. I'll be back for sure. I'll be back for sure!
author: Kyle G.

description: The wines aren't something special. However their food dishes aren't so bad, especially the salads. One thing that annoys the crap out of me is because I live so close by, I can hear all their music. Calm it down!
author: Vinson H.

description:
I called and left a message about reserving a table. I gave all of my information, but they did not return my call. When I arrived at the place, they told me they would be closing in 15 minutes for a private event. I have work in customer service/dining/bar for a long time. It is common courtesy to return all calls even if you cannot accommodate the party. They could have at least let me know so I could have made other arrangements. It was my birthday so it was pretty frustrating to have to scramble to find another place. 

I gave an additional star, because the place looked really cool and the server was prompt. I would like to come back and hopefully leave a better review.
author: Lauren M.

description:
Multiple visits
Averaging 2 weekly visits

My bf and I love to come here to get some "couch time", that is, to sit in one of their two comfortable couches and sip some wines. You'll be lucky to get them if you arrive early or on a slower weeknights. In general, there is no bad seat in Blush. We also love the table by the window facing Castro--the "soft serve window." :)

Blush makes slight modifications to their menu from time to time. The most recent changes have rid off one of our favorite pinot noir by Spencer Santa Cruz, replacing with another one from the same region, Downhill ($12). We also love the Sancerre sauvignon blanc from Loire Valley, France ($12).  Côtes du Rhône red is also good with a fuller body. 

Food-wise I recommend the chicken skewer and the various salads. I'm not a huge fan of cheese but judging from the ubiquitous presence of cheese plates during our visits they are to be recommended as well. The lava chocolate cake is delicious.

Blush has live music on Thursday night. Also look for a house psychic/tarot reader on Wed. He's the one at the candle lit table. They open for brunch on weekend so you can get your Croque Madame. Service is always friendly and attentive. The place gets busy on weekend so you just have to wait and get your drinks at the counter. This is a great uppity alternative to the noisy and smelly bars in the neighborhood.
author: Matt Y.

description: Love this place. Always come here whenever I have the rare day that I'm not at work. Half off all wine for their happy hour is amazing. Large selections by the glass and a good price for the quality. Always can't refuse their fig and prosciutto sandwich. So flavorful. Bartenders are super nice and attentive. Definitely one of my favorite wine bars here in SF
author: Angel R.

description:
We came here on a Thursday to listen to Americano Social Club live and they were perfect for a rainy SF night. A very small cafe ambiance, cozy seating areas and a lot of good conversations all around. The wine selection was mix of affordable, a few good regions and a few good names. We had the bruschetta and it was good but not memorable.

We will definitely come back to listen to live music, drink some wine and cozy up with Blush again!
author: Theresa N.

description:
A divine li'l spot, so long as it's not packed! Can be overloaded with folks on busy weekends, but sparse during others, so you've just gotta find the right time. Bar seating, tables and comfy couches!

Definitely come for their red wines, such as their Meritage from Masked Rider. Good mimosas, too, if you're in that kind of a mood. Even tried some of their brunch food before and it was decent -- tried their Croque Madame and I savored the entire dish.

Also like that they appreciate local art by hanging it on the walls for sale. Saw one piece depicting "Lincoln was a Punk" that has never left my mind, and it was sold and gone the next day.
author: Garett T.

description:
Loved this spot! Great atmosphere, not too rowdy, delicious food and wine. The guys here were super attentive and sweet - will definitely come back soon. 

I snacked on the charcuterie platter while my bf had the B.L.A.T sandwich (can't go wrong with the basics) We weren't too hungry so didn't order anything else but will def explore the menu next time.
author: Janet P.

description:
About the food: YUM, their waffles are delish! I had the smoked salmon platter, super interactive and tasty. However the real gem was the chicken and waffles dish. The collard greens were tangy and crispy, and the chicken was seasoned to perfection. However, portion size wasn't as impressive for the $14 price tag, as there was only half a waffle on the plate. However, if you're looking for a nice spot to hang out with friends, they have bottomless mimosas for $9!

About the service: there was only one waitress and they have a small (but creative) kitchen. That being said, my group waited 40 minutes for our food to come, and our drinks weren't being continuously refilled, even though we had bottomless mimosas. We had to call the waitress many times, which made us feel awkward.
author: Samantha C.

description:
Live music Thursday night, place packed out... Lucky enough that our group landed one of the two couches available. This is a wine bar, but the noise level was off the charts the evening we were here for some hangout time and to meet some new folks. 

My friend Ro's suggestion.. she had a glass of Sancerre, myself a sweet rose, and tried too friend S's tempranillo. There are always a few specials; see sandwich board.

Warm and relatively small, but popular spot in the Castro!
author: Jana C.

description: Cool little wine bar. The wine selection is pretty solid. I order a Pinot Grigio while my friend had a Cabernet. Typical wine bar food - small dishes so don't come here starving! Perfect little place to catch up with friends over a nice glass (or several) of wine. Bonus: they have live music several nights a week which really adds to the ambiance. The only drawback is that it can get a little loud and the service was spotty. Overall fun place and definitely worth checking out. I mean who can go wrong with wine right?
author: Sami F.

description:
Wine: nice. Ambiance: nice. Location: good. Barman with toothpick hanging out of his mouth the entire 90 min. we were there: GROSS! 
I'm easy to please but this was so trashy. This guy was right out of the trailer park, had attitude and believe me, he had no business throwing it around.
author: Andreas M.

description:
I went here for their brunch (which is exclusively waffles). I had the Three Cheese Waffle Tartine that has a fried egg and choice of ham, bacon, or caramelized onions (I chose bacon). It was excellent: a combination of savory and sweet (with the added maple syrup), crunchy and gooey. The French-pressed coffee was also very good.

My caveats are that the service was a tad slow and that they open too late. (I'd prefer they opened at 9 or at least 10am.) Because of that, I probably won't go there too regularly, although I might like to, because I'm just too hungry by 11 (plus, by the time you order and get served, it's more like 11:30).
author: Paul L.

description: Randomly found this place and woohoo! Happy hour gives you the opportunity to taste well-chosen, good brands of wines. People are nice, and the atmosphere is lovely as well.
author: Denis Gudin F.

description:
I have been to Blush several times over the years, the wine, food, ambiance and entertainment are all very enjoyable.  It's a great atmosphere for those simpler times and conversations with friends or new companions.

However, I was here a couple weeks ago on a Thursday night with a friend trying to indulge our love for wine, the issue we had was not with the wines but with the service. I had a tasting of the 2009 Masked Rider Meritage and enjoyed it so we ordered a bottle.  Unfortunately the newly opened bottle needed to breathe and we were semi pressed for time (less than an hour before we had to leave).  I asked for a aerator and the staff gave me a dumbfounded look with the response that they did not have one.  Which, for a wine bar seemed odd to us.  About 15 minutes later, we asked for a decanter and the response the staff gave more than surprised us but encouraged this review; "Oh, I thought you two were joking about that (letting the wine breathe)."  

No aerator. No decanter.  We were left with an unfulfilled experience and a bottle of wine that was rushed and therefore not at the potential we initially enjoyed.
author: Jennifer M.

description:
I had a very good Time there !!

I went to the french party every last monday of the month. French actors are doing stand up and improvisation ! So funny ! 

About the bar : they have really good wines from all around the world! I got a Reisling ( German white win) with a delicious tasty and amazing prosciutto sandwich ! It was a rosemary bread .... I can't tell more about it ! You had to try ! 

I recommend this place ! 
See you next last Monday :)
author: Laura B.

description:
Came here on a Saturday night.  This is a nice quiet wine bar away from all the madness happening on Castro, if that's your thing.  

The bartender was very helpful in helping me pick out a wine. I was a little surprised by how many non-California wines were on the list, but this is a plus for those looking for variety.  I had a Napa Valley Zinfandel. 

The decor of this place is nice with couches and wine bottle shelves and an area for people watching by the window.  Basically, there is a little of everything and we had a good time.
author: Ninette C.

description:
I don't know the Castro area too well, but managed to stumble upon this hidden gem. 

Every Thursday they have live music, the same band. The band on Thursdays is unreal. Listening to them with a glass of the Pinot Noir. What more can you ask for? The band really engages the crowd, I love the vibe of this place.

The atmosphere is a mix between the after-work yuppies and some slightly older married couples. If you're in the area on a Thursday it's probably one of the more interesting places to try in the city. I'll be back.
author: Brad M.

description: Saturday bottomless mimosas and brunch mmmmmmmmmmm! The arugala salad was wonderful and very fresh. The drinks were good. $9 for bottomless when you order a brunch food item. Salad was $4 cheap day out. The bartender, Kristen is very warm and friendly.
author: Riley K.

description:
Blush is a super cute spot.  Go get some wine there.
Nice wines, live music, good times.
author: Kelly C.

description:
went here for HH with a friend after work!

I really like the atmosphere and live music. Food was good too! surprisingly it was really delicious for a food at a wine bar :) recommend!
author: Christine K.

description:
What an oasis from the usual Castro fare!  Not that I can ever complain about a stiff one at Q bar, or the outdoor patio at the mixx, but to peruse the updated wine list or small bites list is just a wonderful after work treat.
In fact, I had to work this Sunday and came in for an afternoon/brunch beverage and was overwhelmed by how amazing the service, drinks and food were. I work in food service, but I cannot compare to the efficiency, attention and hospitality I received today.
I just want to thank the owners for continuing to strive for an excellent wine bar experience both in selection and in service, and for the staff for upholding this standard.
KUDOS!!!
author: Emily D.

description:
Love this place. Relaxed atmosphere, great wine/beer/cheese plates, always good music in the background.  It is our go to spot in Castro/Noe Valley.

Recently tried a few their brunch waffles too which were inventive and delicious.  Will definitely be back to sample the rest of the menu.

We always recommend this place to friends who are in the area and they are always impressed.

Keep up the good work Blush.
author: Shaun G.

description: I like the ambiance and especially LIVE MUSIC during week nights. I love it. Their wine collection is fine, I'm falling for Cabernet Franc. Food is ok, not very outstanding. Service is nice. Wish it could have more seating.
author: Phuong P.

description: Venue was great, but service sucked. Had a cracked glass, tried to get the bartenders attention for fifteen minutes and was ignored the whole time. Then tried to order a next drink and was told they called final call. Which was fine, except that they started pouring champagne drinks right after. Cool spot, never coming back though.
author: Justin O.

description:
Sometimes circumstance is everything, so my friends and I were happy to rest at the relatively low-key Blush after a busy day of walking all over the city. The drinks were very good, as was the olive tapenade and the cheese plate. I actually still dream of that cheese plate from time to time.

We sat in front of the windows and enjoyed a bit of open-air dining and people watching, and our server/bartender was friendly enough for my taste. But then, I get annoyed at overly-attentive service, so I don't mind having to walk to the bar to settle the tab.
author: Laura G.

description: Had three really nice visits here, two with friends and one as a date night with my husband.  Chill atmosphere, and crowd, I love couches good wine and desert, super cute bartender, I mean sommelier.  I was content.
author: Mark R.

description: The wine and cheese atmosphere is wonderful and the staff is incredible. Finding out that we are from Texas the bartender was happy to tell us places to go. Even in Texas I have never experienced a warm and homey experience. This was customer service at its best! A must see and a place we will return to again, when we are in San Francisco!!!
author: Katelin M.

description: We got advised by a friend to try out this wine bar in Castro and were pretty happy about it. My friend and I took place in a big sofa which felt awesome after a day walking around. When comparing prices between a glass and a bottle we quickly concluded we should go for the bottle. However when asking the waiter for a recommendation he brought us wine only sold by the glass, misunderstanding I guess. I explained him that we were actually going for a bottle and he left us the bottle he used that was 4/5 full. He said we could drink as much as we wanted and he would make us a price. This proposition can be tricky because you have no clue how much you will end up paying but we decided to enjoy our wine and figure it out later. Two others friends joined us and even though the place is not really charming we had a lot of fun. When asking for the bill, the waiter asked us the equivalent of 3,5 glasses although we had finished the bottle and pretty much had 2,5 glasses each. Great deal thus from this very friendly bartender.
author: Laura N.

description: Nice relaxed wine bar. Chill atmosphere with lots of seating alternatives and a good menu. You sort of forget you're in the Castro when you're here - other than the naked guy who walked in. I liked my tempranillo. Waitress was sort of surly, but other than that, I like it.
author: Andrew K.

description: Servers could not have been less interested in our presence. Smiled and made eye contact with the staff a few times as they walked by and watched a couple of them repeatedly dote on someone who must have been a friend at the table next to ours. After 10 minutes of waiting, we called it quits and left.
author: Matt L.

description: Wine and beer selection are fine, but as many others have stated the service is something to be desired. The waitress may or not have been drunk on a Sunday afternoon, asking if we would like to order any food about 20 minutes after taking our food order. Yikes. Mind you, it was not busy- only about 5 parties of 2 in the whole bar. The place has great potential, but the service will likely be the downfall of this cute establishment.
author: Sara J.

description:
To take you from what happened, I did eat my dinner from Catch Isle and Cako, and my friend decided to call me and asked if I wanted to join him and his company in Castro. Now, this is my first time taking the Muni down to Castro, so I had no idea which train route to take, and was worried about getting lost at night. No story behind it, and managed to find my way to Castro with little trouble. (Thank goodness).

Now, I'm not a big wine person, because I just started diving into the world of wine. I only know my moscato, which is pretty sad, but I'll start growing when I have a depose-able income. My friend ordered the moscato here for me, and I have to say, this moscato in comparison to the others I've tried from the bottle, it has less of an alcohol taste and more apple-flavoring, if that makes any sense.

My friend also ordered the triple macaron, and to be honest, I felt like this place should stick to being a wine bar, and not have dessert on the side. It's decent, but I've only had 'lette (down in SoCal), and it seems to be a bit better with the outer shell. The ones in Blush tasted too chewy with not enough air in the batter, while the chocolate sauce kind of cancelled out the actual flavor of the macaron, which I don't even remember what the flavors were.

Good wine, not so good dessert.
author: Tom T.

description: Still great wine, food and music, great staff, but...they discontinued the apple crisp. :-(
author: Bill F.

description:
I've been to Blush several times and even though it's a nice space to grab a glass of wine where the rest or the area is surrounded by cocktails and debauchery I can't say I've ever had outstanding service here.  The last time I was here my friend and I had a seat on the couch as we ordered our wine, but the lady who gave us menus seemed to have a chip on her shoulder for some reason.  Everything was met with a snarl and a little attitude when ordering and paying.  I was happy that she carded us and everyone has a bad day but if I'm friendly, you should be too.

Good wines, but lacking in great service.
author: Kevin J.

description:
I met a friend here for a friend-date and it was the perfect little spot to catch up with her. We sat at the bar and watched the transition from slow to very busy (7:30pm -9:30pm on a week-night). The wine selections were good. I was in the mood for an Oregon Pinot Nior though, and I was a little bummed that they didn't have one. 

The bartender was friendly and engaging with all the patrons, and she was very knowledgeable of the wines and was able to help me select a wine for my mood. 

The ambiance was great and my friend ordered a salad that she seemed to enjoy.

I will totally come back again!
author: Kristen M.

description: What is up with the bartenders at this place? It's as if they actually ENJOY working there! We had a great time at Blush! The service was just so fantastic. I mean, it was like the dudes behind the bar were reading our minds. Saturday night after 10 pm and they were on. Looking forward to going back for brunch Or happy hour...
author: Jim H.

description: My friend and I went for the first time the other day.  I like the spot and all that it offers, but had NO idea they served food!  We popped in after dinner, so we weren't able to try anything.  The customer service and offerings were good, so we'll go back and recommend it to others.  Hopefully we'll try the food soon!
author: Shaun W.

description: Nice place, but they seem to be understaffed. Takes about 10 minutes to get your first order, then 20 minutes after that and we were sitting at the counter . To bad as I really like this place, just not managed well..
author: Ron J.

description:
Blush just keeps getting better! The selections on offer are wonderful and well priced, the chow delicious, and the crowd entertaining. 

It's still a bit loud but they have managed to quiet the place down with a few touches. 

Very glad they are part of the Castro.
author: William M.

description: Great place to take your date, boss, or family member. Quiet atmosphere and the food is priced very well especially for how good it is.
author: Peter F.

description: A chic spot with a good variety of vintages. Occasionally they'll host the tried starving artist, who may request your patronage. The sandwiches are quite delectable but their smaller platters may leave wondering what you paid for. Overall a good experience and a subdued and understated atmosphere.
author: Alex C.

description: Great selection of wines and fun ambience. Enjoyed the metallic image exhibit and the family style table. Recommend highly.
author: Ara A.

description:
Decent enough, the wine we had was good, and the oysters were fresh and tasty.  The fruit salad was a miss for me, next time I'll know to order it without the powdered sugar sprinkled on top.

I had the odd sensation of being in a dive bar and a wine bar at the same time.  It wasn't a bad thing, just a bit of a cognitive dissonance.  They don't do flights, but they were really nice about letting me try a couple of things before I landed on what I wanted.

I don't think Blush will unseat any of my current favorite Castro watering holes, but I would definitely be up for giving them another go.
author: Renae H.

description:
15-September, Saturday:
It's nice to have a redux with a calm, slow glass of Pinot in compliment to good conversation with company and friends every once in a while. Especially living in the Castro, and without having to walk over to the Noe side.. because lately it seems like all the bars around here have 1 thing in common.. Stiff drinks with a splash of tonic, which even at the request of quality liquor is most times overwhelming since I only prefer gin.

"There's a famous saying: Like schoolboys, Rieslings are best enjoyed young." -Posh Nosh

Cheers!
author: Ty T.

description: Enjoyed the ambience was cozy and cute. Came during pride weekend and was nice to get out of the crowd it was relaxing.
author: April C.

description: The wines are decent, but nothing to get excited about at all.  It's a nice place to meet friends in the evening for a drink. The bartenders are always very nice and welcoming.  I feel bad for them, however: management can't seem to get staffing right.  Often there will be a single bartender scurrying around the place trying to serve thirty or more people, which means you can sit for ages before placing an order.  Also, something really needs to be done about the kitchen.  Sometimes it's fine, and you get your food within a reasonable time.  At other times, it's ridiculous--half an hour or more to get some tapenade and a few crackers.  I realize their closest competition is on Valencia Street 3/4 of a mile away, but seriously... on more than a few occasions, I feel like we could have walked to Valencia, had some (vastly more interesting) wine and appetizers, and then walked back to 18th and Castro in the amount of time it would have taken Blush to fill our food order.
author: Mike M.

description: Good place to stay, to drink a glass of wine and eat some bruschettas :). I really liked that place. I went there yesterday night, the staff is nice and I love the decoration !
author: Pri A.

description: Best wine bar in San Francisco. Everything is good. EVERYTHING! From the wine to the food to the staff to the ambiance. I love this place.
author: Lisa N.

description: I come here fairly regularly - mostly for the ambience and not the wine or service.  Although the food use to be probably a 4... however it is lower since they took the fig and arugula pizza off the menu.  Tonight this was an   "end of the night" stop for me.  Wanted a nice glass of wine.  I got it.  Wanted a dessert cheese plate.  I got it.  Service was poor.  The staff here tends to get caught up in conversations with one or two and neglect the rest.  Not once did the server ask me if the food and wine were good.  He never came back to ask if I needed anything else.  This is not a unique occurrence here.  This is one of those places that could rock if the owners paid attention to service, staff, and selection because the decor rocks and the unique potential is there - no other place in castro has this atmosphere.
author: James W.

description:
The space is nice, the wines are nice. Others have already covered it, but the service sucks, by American standards.

Just prior to my last visit to Blush, I had just read an essay about how different cultures think differently about time. If you are American and think of time linearly and expect a menu when you walk in, to be asked what you would like to drink shortly after being given the menu, to be asked whether you want another drink after you've finished the first, or to be given a check when you clearly look ready to leave, you may go insane here.

If, on the other hand, you take the southern European way of viewing time, which is based on completing encounters rather than on sticking to a rigid schedule, you'll be fine. Recognize that you will be served when the staff finishes the conversation they are having with whoever they're catching up with, or when they're through with shuffling things around by the register, and you can retain inner tranquility. Don't try to get the staff's attention while they are busy with these other duties; it will just annoy the both of you.
author: Charles D.

description: Service was not the greatest I was over charged and waited for food while others orders kept coming out. Was told I would be comped never happen. Just not s place I don't want to revisit.
author: RICHARD J.

description:
A truly neighborhood wine bar. Reliable and informative staff, a little kitchen that can deliver on apps....good feelings among patrons and others who wander in.

I miss the dollar oysters though, it has gone up in price.

I tend to return at least once a month because it is comfy...
author: One P.

description: They topped up our glasses a few times. We though it was very nice. However, we were charged for 5 glasses when we only ordered 3. This is one of our experiences from visiting San Francisco. Not cool.
author: Alec M.

description: Love the food there! A real taste of France (and I am French). If you have never tried the Ravioles, now is the time! Good selection of wine, friendly staff!
author: Dimitri S.

description: Revising my old review. Were there today, great server (unlike last time), great wine (unlike last time). I like blush now!
author: Hendrik G.

description:
I came here with a friend based on his recommendation. The wine we had was fine; however, I couldn't attest to the food we intended to have because of the service, which I must say was probably the worst I experienced in a long time. 

The waitress was anything but pleasant: she didn't smile or show any hint of courtesy towards us at all. We ordered our wine and she brought that order to us promptly; however, she simply placed the glasses down and walked away from us. She didn't asked us if we wanted any food or ever bothered to come around to ask us how we liked the wine we ordered. She only came back around after 30 minutes because I raised my hand to get her attention to get the bill and leave. She never said thank you.

Needless to say, I wouldn't return to this establishment and risk being waited on again by this same individual who, in my estimation, does not belong in the service industry. The goal is ensure repeat business, not drive away patrons. There are too many other wine bar establishments that I can go to and reasonably expect decent service.
author: Robert S.

description: New wine bar! Great atmosphere, excellent service and the food is better than typical bar menu. It's not complex... Just yummy. We will be back again next week. Check it out!
author: Kimberly R.

description: Great food, great wine selection and great atmosphere. The Ravioli is amazing, and so is the prosciutto hot sub.
author: Lihi W.

description:
It's awesome to have a wine bar option in the Castro as an alternative to places with only a choice of red versus white and no chance at an intimate conversation.  Their menu is more extensive than just food plates so I'd say it almost qualifies as a restaurant.  And as a restaurant, it's just ok.

Croque-Madame: Standard.  Ham, cheese, egg on bread.  Satisfies your hunger.  Tastier than American diner versions though doesn't compare to many French bistro attempts.

Spicy Blush Kobe Beef Tartare: Spicy wasn't that spicy.  Texture seemed machine processed rather than hand chopped.  The typical capers, cornichon and onions were in the mix.  I've had worse, but have also had better.

Raviole de Royan: Probably the most standout item I've tried here.  Super creamy comté sauce encasing midget-sized raviole.  Way more sauce than pasta, which is ok by me since it made an awesome fondue-like dipping sauce. 

Escargots de Bourgogne en Persillade: Typical snails in garlic butter sauce.  Tasty as always.  I like that they put them in the ceremonial snail shell and give the special escargot tongs so there is always the risk of being like that ho in Pretty Woman.
author: Adam B.

description: Fun place. Check out happy hour Monday's for dirty bingo! All wine 50% off. Awesome deal, cool atmosphere, very modern hip decor. They also have some very tasty bites including some delicious cheese plates. I will definitely be back :)
author: Genevieve N.

description: The worst service ever!!Waiting for more than 20 minutes to order for a bottle of wine and a small plate! The food, so and so. Disappointing
author: Jude D.

description:
Such a cool wine bar in the Castro.

One of the reasons why I don't travel to the Castro very often is that, most of the places aren't all that appealing.  I was here with a  friend recently and had a great time at this spot.  The ambiance is low-key, but cool.  The wine selection is fantastic and the servers are chill and friendly.  It actually feels like an escape from some of the hectic scene outside.

With a place like this, it's nice to have an alternative option to the mostly divey and loud establishments in the area.
author: Ken G.

description:
A rare find in the Castro:  A Cozy, warm, intimate wine bar.  Sans flamboyance. 

I dig it.

Lovely ambiance.  So quiet that you can actually carry on a conversation!  Choose from a great selection of wines, then sit at the bar, a table, or one of the never-want-to-get-up couches.   And oh yes, they have nibbles.  

I'm no wine snob, so I totally appreciate an establishment with such a low-key and friendly staff...Not to mention that it's walking distance from my house ;)  (Which, by the way, has no bearing on my 5-star rating!).
author: Angella S.

description:
One of the tricks to understanding Blush is that it is one of the few places in the city--yes, really, the city (note: native San Franciscan writing here)--where your party can get nice wine AND nice Belgian beer on draft AND sit comfortably AND hear one another talk AND get nice nibblies. Not one beer, either, but four (always the same four, which is fine by me): Duvel green label, Chimay white label, La Chouffe IPA, and Maredsous (which at 10% is kind of an event all by itself). Oh yes, and Anchor Steam and Blue Moon for your Uncle Roy from Milwaukee who don't like them thar furrin beers and ain't never had a wine he liked. 

The wine lineup may not be extensive, but it's always good, and having paid silly amounts elsewhere for wine that was merely meh, I appreciate that. A nice Sonoma wine in the vicinity of $8 for a generous pour, in a humanely comfortable setting: go try doing that elsewhere in the Castro, or most of the city. 

The food plates are terrific for what they are -- simple accompaniments to a decent glass of beer or wine. We have done the cheese plates, the fish plates, the oysters,the olives, the tapenade... it's all good. In fact, more than once we have made it a meal, and frankly, it is one of the better places to dine on Castro Street proper if you are not a big eater and are not looking for a major sit-down dinner or do not want a forgettable burger/pizza/etc. The Alsatian pizza and Croque-Monsieurs look good, too (though I'd rather spend my carb count on the beer). 

Many Castro Street restaurants are tiny and crowded, with seating that feels cramped and is either by the kitchen or (as happened last night, in an incident that drove us to walk out of a restaurant before ordering after waiting over an hour to get in) near a banging door that blows in an icy draft every minute. In comparison, almost all of the seating in Blush is *comfortable.*  It's a mellow setting that in one small storefront manages to have window seats, a bar, small tables, couches, and a great long table where you can sit absorbed in your beer and your iPad or mingle/chat with others. If it's full, you may not get one of the choice spots, but none of the seating is outright uncomfortable--again, for the Castro, high praise. 

The art is always interesting (even when it is odd, like the blacklight exhibit--unlike another reviewer, I kind of liked that one; it's not like they were twisting my arm to buy the stuff) and the service is personable and knowledgeable without getting in your face. 

The noise level varies, but on a weekend night this is one of the few places that is likely to be comfortable and not over-the-top noisy. On an early weeknight when it's not a major holiday, Blush can be serene, even when full. Last night the music briefly got on a weird jangly techno-something jag... after five minutes my partner asked if the music could be changed, and the server could not have been more courteous or moved more swiftly. (In my fantasies, Blush has a jukebox featuring Edith Piaf and Nina Simone... but at least the music is usually pleasant.)

There is at least one review suggesting that inebriated blowhards looking for a new perch for their obnoxious behavior will get the message that while they may patronize the establishment, an extended drinking session will not be encouraged. To that I say: thank you. 

I do sometimes wish they would surprise me with Delirium Tremens on tap or even sneak in a (gasp) American Belgian, like Damnation or Matilda. But that's a small quibble. This review has been overdue, but a pleasure to finally write. Yes, five stars, not awarded lightly, after two years of enjoying this little bit of heaven.
author: Karen S.

description: Elliott was the best!  He gave us the best drinks and service!  I'm actually looking forward to seeing him next time ;-)
author: Jacquelyn G.

description:
Great service, cute bartenders (who are smart about wine and will give you as many tastes as you'd like!).  Also helps that they're lenient on the $20 credit card minimum.
